tweets.text:
üßµ9/10 - Limitations of LLN ‚ö†Ô∏è

Keep in mind that LLN doesn't guarantee a specific outcome in any single trial, and it doesn't say how fast the convergence occurs. The speed of convergence depends on the specific problem.

#Statistics #Probability #RStats #DataScience

üßµ8/10 - Real-World Applications üåé

LLN has many real-world applications, such as predicting stock prices, insurance premium calculations, and assessing the performance of machine learning models.

#RStats #DataScience #MachineLearning

üßµ7/10 - Interpreting the Plot üìà

The plot shows that as the number of trials increases, the proportion of H converges to 0.5, confirming the Law of Large Numbers.

#RStats #DataScience

ylim(c(0,1)) +
scale_x_log10() +
labs(title = "Law of Large Numbers - Coin Flips",
x = "Number of Trials",
y = "Proportion of Heads")

#RStats #DataScience https://t.co/k5NdKM6Soa

üßµ6/10 - R: Visualizing the Results üìâ

We'll use ggplot2 to visualize the results:

library(ggplot2)

data <- data.frame(n_trials, proportion_heads)
ggplot(data, aes(x = n_trials, y = proportion_heads)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0.5, linetype = "dashed") +

üßµ3/10 - Coin Flip Example ü™ô

Imagine flipping a fair coin. The probability of getting heads (H) is 0.5. As we increase the number of flips, the proportion of H should approach 0.5. Let's see this in action with R!

#RStats #DataScience

üßµ2/10 - What is LLN? üßê

LLN states that as the number of trials (n) in a random experiment increases, the average of the outcomes converges to the expected value. In other words, the more we repeat an experiment, the closer we get to the true probability.

#RStats  #DataScience

üßµ1/10 - Law of Large Numbers (LLN) in R üìà

Hello #Rstats community! Today, we're going to explore the Law of Large Numbers (LLN), a fundamental concept in probability theory, and how to demonstrate it using R. Get ready for some code! üöÄ

#Probability #Statistics #DataScience https://t.co/d0vCPXLzG3

7/üîç As you can see, the distribution of sample means becomes more normal as the sample size increases, just as the Central Limit Theorem predicts. This holds true even though we started with a uniform distribution! #CLT #RStats #DataScience

geom_density(color = "red", size = 1) +
labs(title = paste("n =", n_values[i]),
x = "Sample Means", y = "Density") +
theme_minimal()
})
https://t.co/lE0038qpVh("grid.arrange", c(plots, ncol = 2))
}
plot_sample_means(simulated_means, n_values) https://t.co/2t9J8Ubwa3

library(ggplot2)
library(gridExtra)
set.seed(42)
sample_means <- function(dist_function, n, 
                         sample_size, iterations) {
  means <- replicate(iterations, mean(dist_function(n)))
  data.frame(SampleMeans = means)
}

3/üîë Why is the CLT important? It allows us to make inferences about population parameters using sample data. Since many statistical tests assume normality, CLT gives us the foundation to apply those tests even when the underlying population is not normally distributed. #RStats

2/üìö The Central Limit Theorem states that the distribution of sample means approaches a normal distribution as the sample size (n) increases, given that the population has a finite mean and variance. It's a cornerstone of inferential statistics! #CLT #DataScience #RStats

1/üßµ Welcome to this thread on the Central Limit Theorem (CLT), a key concept in statistics! We'll cover what the CLT is, why it's essential, and how to demonstrate it using R. Grab a cup of coffee and let's dive in! ‚òïÔ∏è #statistics #datascience #rstats https://t.co/pJ2tm11FkP
@LoredanaBellan1 @LSportel4  @lcolladotor @getneuro @Robinson_Karen1 @PhiloNeuroSci @JooHeonSHIN @klmmph31 https://t.co/6898exdny3

urls.title: vip: Variable Importance Plots
urls.description: A general framework for constructing variable importance plots from various types of machine learning models in R. Aside from some standard model- specific variable importance measures, this package also provides model- agnostic approaches that can be applied to any supervised learning algorithm. These include 1) an efficient permutation-based variable importance measure, 2) variable importance based on Shapley values (Strumbelj and Kononenko, 2014) <doi:10.1007/s10115-013-0679-x>, and 3) the variance-based approach described in Greenwell et al. (2018) <arXiv:1805.04755>. A variance-based method for quantifying the relative strength of interaction effects is also included (see the previous reference for details).

tweets.text:
[5/11] üåü vip: Variable importance plots - Visualize the importance of variables in your models using #vip. Great for model interpretation and understanding feature influence! #rstats #datascience #machinelearning 
üîó https://t.co/O4Cyw59ns6

urls.title: recipes: Preprocessing and Feature Engineering Steps for Modeling
urls.description: A recipe prepares your data for modeling. We provide an extensible framework for pipeable sequences of feature engineering steps provides preprocessing tools to be applied to data. Statistical parameters for the steps can be estimated from an initial data set and then applied to other data sets. The resulting processed output can then be used as inputs for statistical or machine learning models.

urls.title: caretEnsemble: Ensembles of Caret Models
urls.description: Functions for creating ensembles of caret models: caretList() and caretStack(). caretList() is a convenience function for fitting multiple caret::train() models to the same dataset. caretStack() will make linear or non-linear combinations of these models, using a caret::train() model as a meta-model, and caretEnsemble() will make a robust linear combination of models using a GLM.

8/ üöÄ Case Studies: Apply web scraping and text mining techniques to real-world problems, such as:
‚Ä¢Social media sentiment analysis
‚Ä¢Web content summarization
‚Ä¢Trend and keyword analysis

7/ üìä Visualizing Text Data: Create insightful visualizations with:
‚Ä¢ggplot2 for word frequency plots and bar charts
‚Ä¢wordcloud or wordcloud2 for visually appealing word clouds

6/ üí° Advanced Text Mining Techniques: Explore sophisticated text mining methods like:
‚Ä¢Word embeddings with word2vec or GloVe
‚Ä¢Text classification with RTextTools or caret
‚Ä¢Network analysis with igraph or tidygraph
#rstats #AdvancedR #datascience

5/ ü§ñ Natural Language Processing: Analyze text data with powerful NLP techniques using:
‚Ä¢tidytext for text analysis in the tidyverse
‚Ä¢sentimentr for sentiment analysis
‚Ä¢spacyr for part-of-speech tagging and dependency parsing
‚Ä¢topicmodels for topic modeling 
#rstats

4/ üìö Text Processing: Clean and preprocess text data using:

‚Ä¢tidyr for reshaping and cleaning text data

‚Ä¢quanteda for advanced text processing
#rstats #AdvancedR #datascience

3/üß™ Advanced Web Scraping Techniques: Go beyond basic scraping with:
‚Ä¢Setting up custom headers and cookies with httr

‚Ä¢Throttling requests to avoid getting blocked
‚Ä¢Using proxy servers to bypass restrictions
#rstats #AdvancedR

2/ üï∏Ô∏è Web Scraping: Extract data from websites using powerful R tools:

‚Ä¢xml2 for handling XML and XPath queries
‚Ä¢RSelenium for scraping dynamic web content
#rstats #datascience #AdvancedR
